body: This looks like you might have installed a new version of NumPy after building pandas-- is that right? Otherwise do you have a separate version of Python installed in /Library/Frameworks? I usually recommend that people install and use python.org Python instead of using Apple's Python.
hi, did you resolve this by rebuilding pandas?

Nope i need to install Python, easy_install, np etc first... Is in my
todo list for this weekend

Thanks for asking!

Alberto
Sent from my iPhone

You've got an old version of scikits.statsmodels-- try upgrading to version 0.3.0 or higher (latest is 0.3.1). Feel free to install xlrd if you wish, I'll make a note to skip tests depending on xlrd (reading Excel 2003 files) if it's not installed.

What about the other 100-ish errors?

I have tried a new setup using virtualenv and it worse now (132 errors)....
back to activePython, the other problem I have is somehow ipython and nose
are pointing out the old env and I have no visibility of the new one but
when type idle or python in the terminal it brings the latest
installation.... very frustrating

I am tempted to install 2.7 from python.org to finally mess up my laptop...
Does pandas/numpy support 2.7???

Thanks for your support.

I'm not sure this bug should be closed. We just ran into a whole lot of these test errors on Python 2.6 when when had inadvertently installed dateutil 2.0. Installing dateutil 1.5 made them go away, but to find that, we had to find this page and read the whole thing. It would be nice if pandas (at least when running the test suite) checked the Python and dateutils versions for known incompatibilities.

I can have it raise a more helpful import error on Python 2.x if dateutil 2.0 is installed:

https://github.com/wesm/pandas/issues/346

You don't have `dateutil` module, need to install python-dateutil 1.5 (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-dateutil/1.5) per the message (https://github.com/wesm/pandas/blob/master/README.rst). Before there was a slightly cryptic error when users installed the Python 3-only dateutil 2.0

Yes, pip installing dateutil for 3.x on a 2.x system is pip's problem and very annoying.
